title: Annual Employment Changes by Age and Level of AI Exposure
text:

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text: DAIOE tracks how advances in artificial intelligence change the potential impact of AI on different occupations over time. It‚Äôs a panel index (2010‚Äì) that updates annually and distinguishes between nine major AI subdomains (e.g., language modeling, image generation, speech recognition). Think of it as a moving barometer of where AI capabilities could matter most‚Äînot as a forecast of job loss or gain. The net employment effect, e.g., depends on how organisations adopt and apply AI.

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text: DAIOE tracks how advances in artificial intelligence change the potential impact of AI on different occupations over time. It‚Äôs a panel index (2010‚Äì) that updates annually and distinguishes between nine major AI subdomains (e.g., language modeling, image generation, speech recognition). Think of it as a moving barometer of where AI capabilities could matter most‚Äînot as a forecast of job loss or gain. The net employment effect, e.g., depends on how organisations adopt and apply AI.

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text:
Why it‚Äôs useful?
Because DAIOE is dynamic and subdomain-specific, it‚Äôs better aligned with real technical progress than static, one-shot measures. In essence, it ‚Äúunpacks‚Äù AI‚Äìenabling analysis of how exposed occupations are to different types of AI. By combining DAIOE with other data that have occupation codes, such as industry-level data or linked employer-employee data, researchers and policymakers can trace exposure by occupation, sector, skill level, or country (e.g., Denmark, Portugal, Sweden in our firm-level applications), and test whether AI exposure is associated with up-skilling or reallocation inside firms and industries. In our firm-level evidence, total employment associations are small on average, but exposure is linked to a higher share of high-skilled white-collar work and a lower share of low-skill clerical roles. Meanwhile, results differ meaningfully across different types of AI, underlining the importance of ‚Äúunpacking‚Äù exposure to AI.






NoteDAIOE at a glance




Coverage: 2010‚Äì (currently, 2023)
AI subdomains: 9, related to games, language, and images
Occupations: ISCO-08, SOC2010 and SSYK2012
Granularity: virtually all occupations; sub-indices by subdomain.
Add-ons: one overall and another generative AI version.
Total number of indices: 11 (1 overall; 1 genAI; 9 sub-indices)
Meaning: Exposure = potential applicability of AI capabilities to occupational content (not adoption or automation probability).

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text:
Technical specification (short)
Construction (overview)
DAIOE combines

AI capability progress by subdomain with
Occupational work content.

First, we assemble yearly measures of AI performance across nine applications (e.g., language, vision, speech), drawing on standardised evaluation benchmarks and leaderboards. Second, we map those AI abilities to the skills and abilities that define each occupation. Finally, for each occupation‚Äìyear, we take a weighted aggregation (a ‚Äúmatch‚Äù between capability growth and occupational requirements) to form the exposure index and its nine sub-indices as well as two off-springs (the genAI- and non-genAI versions).

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text:
Formal details

Capturing AI capability progress
We track yearly progress in nine AI subdomains‚Äîgames (abstract strategy, real-time), vision (recognition, comprehension, generation), language (reading comprehension, language modelling, translation), and speech recognition‚Äîusing 140 benchmarks that have been used to test model performance in AI research (sources: EFF and Papers With Code). For each benchmark, we derive a frontier curve, indicating the state-of-the-art at a given time. Metrics are harmonised so changes are comparable, then summarised each year to capture shifts in the technical frontier.


From capabilities to occupations
Subdomain progress is mapped to 52 O*NET abilities via the Felten et al.¬†(2018) 9√ó52 matrix. Ability-level exposure is aggregated to occupations with O*NET importance√ólevel weights, yielding an annual exposure change and nine parallel sub-indices. To pay attention to interpersonal roles, we apply a calibrated social-skills discount and then cumulate the annual exposure changes from 2010‚Äì to form the DAIOE panel.


Interpretation
DAIOE measures the potential applicability of AI to occupational content, over time‚Äînot adoption or automation probabilities. Real-world effects, e.g., depend on the development and adoption of AI applications, complementary investments, organisational choices, and policy.

title: Dynamic AI Occupational Exposure Index
text:
Links
The original paper The DAIOE is developed, explained, validated, and applied in the most current version of the paper by Engberg et al.¬†(2025).
Suggested citation: Engberg et al. (2024)

Engberg, Erik, Holger Gorg, Magnus Lodefalk, Farrukh Javed, Martin L√§ngkvist, Nat√°lia P. Monteiro, Hildegunn Kyvik Nord√•s, Sarah Schroeder, and Aili Tang. 2024. ‚ÄòAI Unboxed and Jobs: A Novel Measure and Firm-Level Evidence from Three Countries‚Äô. SSRN Electronic Journal. https://doi.org/10.2139/ssrn.4691172.
DAIOE data can be downloaded ‚û°Ô∏è Github (2010 to latest available year) and its full documentation specified.

title: FAQs
text:
Does ‚Äúexposure‚Äù mean automation or job loss?

No‚ÄîDAIOE captures potential applicability of AI capabilities to occupational content. Whether this changes jobs, e.g., depends on adoption, complements, and organisational choices. Thus, the DAIOE is ‚Äúagnostic‚Äù about job displacement, augmentation, and other potential effects.



Is it a forecast for AI adoption?

DAIOE captures potential applicability of AI in occupations. If, when and how AI will be applied in an occupation depends, e.g., on the cost of aquiring, adapting and using the technology in that occupation, the institutional setting (e.g., laws and regulations), etc.



What‚Äôs different about DAIOE versus prior indices (e.g., AIOE, patent-based)?

DAIOE is dynamic and grounded in measured AI benchmark progress. It tracks nine subdomains over time and explicitly adjusts for social interaction. Thus, it ‚Äúunpacks‚Äù AI‚Äìenabling analysis of how different areas within AI expose occupational content to its abilities.



Which occupations tend to score highest?

Cognitive, non-physical roles with lower social-interaction intensity‚Äîoften white-collar‚Äîtend to rank higher.



Do the data say anything about employment outcomes?

Across Denmark, Portugal, and Sweden, we find no systematic change in total headcount, but consistent up-skilling: higher DAIOE relates to higher high-/low-skill ratios and a shift from low-skill clerical toward high-skill white-collar work. Blue-collar associations average near zero, with heterogeneity by subdomain.



How do you handle interpersonal-heavy work?

We compute a social-skills index from O*NET (importance √ó level across six social skills) and discount exposure accordingly.



What exactly are the nine AI subdomains?

Games (abstract strategy; real-time video); Vision (recognition, comprehension, generation); Language (reading comprehension, language modelling, translation, speech recognition).



Can I compare across countries or industries?

Yes. Combine occupation-level DAIOE with local workforce structures (firms, industries, regions) to assess exposure distributions.
Is there a ‚ÄúgenAI‚Äù version? We provide a generative-AI sub-index that combines language modelling and image generation.

title: Trends in Employment by Occupation and Age Group
text:
This section examines employment levels across different occupations, age groups, and years. The interactive tool below enables you to explore employment trends over time for various occupations and age demographics.
